channel.title: 华尔街日报热门
channel.description: 用中文浏览华尔街日报热门报道

item.title: McDonald’s is raising menu prices to keep pace with rapidly growing costs, with wages alone up at least 10% so far this year at U.S. restaurants https://t.co/Df542risdO
Some former U.S.-trained Afghan soldiers and spies, abandoned after America's withdrawal and hunted by the Taliban, have enlisted in Islamic State https://t.co/YfQ5w5KXVu

As workers seek exemptions to Covid-19 vaccine mandates, some companies are asking a number of questions, including whether their religious beliefs prevent them from wearing seat belts or taking Tylenol https://t.co/BZ68criRJv
White House press secretary Jen Psaki has tested positive for Covid-19. She says she hadn’t had contact with President Biden or senior White House staff since Wednesday. https://t.co/1o4MwYoUvw
Covid-19 patients who were given the low-cost antidepressant fluvoxamine were significantly less likely to require hospitalization https://t.co/vpd3SlzQBo
A major home builder is teaming with a Texas startup to create a community of 3-D printed homes https://t.co/ieT0QQFPIb

A lawsuit alleges Kellogg’s strawberry Pop-Tarts actually contain more pears and apples, and some fans of the breakfast treat are shocked: “It’s like you just told me there’s no Santa Claus.” https://t.co/ZDANHhPuhY
American Airlines has canceled more than 1,600 flights since Friday, mostly due to lack of available crew, particularly flight attendants, according to internal figures https://t.co/RJyMigjdnQ

Researchers have proven that a man who claimed to be the great-grandson of Sitting Bull truly is related to the legendary Lakota Sioux leader, thanks to new innovations in DNA testing https://t.co/xJGUSgGmFu
G-20 leaders agreed to accelerate plans to tackle climate change but failed to set specific goals, pointing to tough talks at the U.N. COP26 summit https://t.co/ihCbuHC1El

The federal government plans to spend $42 billion to expand broadband access to underserved areas. But the wording of the bill could hide from the public documents about how that money would be spent. https://t.co/udk1KZmRG5

Many companies have been struggling for months to get products to consumers, as they face shortages in everything from raw materials to labor. Some are questioning whether it makes sense to promote products they can’t adequately stock. https://t.co/mTcuq9DrgO

Covid-19 was more than five times more common among hospitalized people who were unvaccinated and had a previous infection, compared with those who were fully vaccinated and hadn’t had Covid-19 before, a new study found https://t.co/n3RxilU2zP

From @WSJopinion: More parents are wising up to the damage that union control of public education hath wrought. Republicans ought to embrace the opportunity to explain to voters why the best response is more school choice, writes @jasonrileywsj https://t.co/tJlLbQeW71
Ahead of COP26, a look at previous attempts to galvanize nations’ response to climate change https://t.co/tFhUMCdEvd
“Halloween” Scream Queen Jamie Lee Curtis has a secret: She loathes horror. ”Even when I was a toddler, I was always looking over my shoulder.” https://t.co/K4D91u77K9

A lawsuit alleges Kellogg’s strawberry Pop-Tarts actually contain more pears and apples, and some fans of the breakfast treat are shocked: “It’s like you just told me there’s no Santa Claus.” https://t.co/0dE9DQQogt
Dating in Lululemons? Why some women are going for a more casual first-date look https://t.co/b7IgFEGaIx
The Shiba Inu coin, a meme cryptocurrency which brands itself the “dogecoin killer,” is surging in value, nipping at the heels of dogecoin #WSJWhatsNow https://t.co/7beWfMfR56

Getting a conviction against Kyle Rittenhouse, the teen who killed two people and injured a third during the unrest in Kenosha, might be harder than it seems. A Wisconsin law makes it difficult to convict someone who claims self-defense. https://t.co/3U504RgoPx
"When you really fall in love with a car, it’s true love," says the owner of an E Type 4.2. "That’s how I felt when I first saw this 1971 Jaguar in 1983." https://t.co/rjAMPJF48O
From @WSJopinion: The $1.75 trillion cost of the White House’s budget framework is phony, but the social and fiscal damage are real. https://t.co/dzMLNpnwp4
Americans purchased more cigarettes last year, the first uptick in more than two decades https://t.co/jY2X82EtbK
Elon Musk’s wealth has soared as Tesla’s market cap surpassed $1 trillion, and investors are betting a rally in the company’s stocks will continue #WSJWhatsNow https://t.co/G5gzyE2ZSu

From @WSJopinion: Net zero emissions by 2050? Don’t plan on it, writes Tom Switzer. By promising an unrealistic transformation, politicians deny poor countries a chance to grow. https://t.co/7ox4AcFT75
The chip shortage is worsening, with wait times lengthening and buyers hoarding products. Delivery dates in 2024 aren't unusual. https://t.co/h5Q1OPypj7
McDonald’s is raising menu prices to keep pace with rapidly growing costs, with wages alone up at least 10% so far this year at U.S. restaurants https://t.co/zes6TSzSqz
Covid-19 patients who were given the low-cost antidepressant fluvoxamine were significantly less likely to require hospitalization https://t.co/PEYAqMxZNd
Crowds of Sudanese protesters put on a show of defiance against a military coup that has disrupted the country’s fragile transition to democracy https://t.co/zKY3rVRw3d

Many companies have been struggling for months to get products to consumers, as they face shortages in everything from raw materials to labor. Some are questioning whether it makes sense to promote products they can’t adequately stock. https://t.co/zdNEnXE3TE
With one of the world’s highest Covid-19 vaccination rates, Portugal is learning to live with the virus and being watched by other countries as a possible way forward https://t.co/Q8A5FWaBfX

Grammy-nominated rapper Fetty Wap was arrested at New York’s Citi Field ballpark Thursday, charged in what prosecutors allege is a drug-trafficking operation involving cocaine, heroin and other opioids https://t.co/RzERza37cX
Researchers at a Wuhan laboratory were probably unaware of the existence of the virus that causes Covid-19 before the pandemic began, according to a U.S. intelligence report https://t.co/MDGgoxKEVi
Take a look at the front page of today's Wall Street Journal https://t.co/h3RrAx3zoD https://t.co/d3wKohm9Da

Sesame Street season 52 was undertaken entirely in the context of the pandemic, and the new episodes reflect that. "We had learned how to make things quickly, with confidence that they were 90 percent right. We’d actually done two Covid town halls." https://t.co/76AzEffa9u
The chip shortage is worsening, with wait times lengthening and buyers hoarding products. Delivery dates in 2024 aren't unusual. https://t.co/rVNl3PvnyF

A federal judge on Friday said he was inclined to require Sen. Richard Burr’s brother-in-law to testify in an investigation that examines whether the two men engaged in insider trading https://t.co/ccCSVUmYHO

Researchers at a Wuhan lab were probably unaware of the existence of the Covid-19 virus before the pandemic began, and if it leaked from the lab, it was likely the result of an accident, a U.S. intelligence report says https://t.co/2MDaShi7Ew
Breaking: Pfizer-BioNTech's Covid vaccine was cleared for use in children ages 5 to 11 by the FDA. Kids could get a first dose within days, once the CDC gives its sign-off. https://t.co/7PdTfPMuQA
Take an early look at the front page of The Wall Street Journal https://t.co/5lEdgjqfpJ https://t.co/6PSrCnK10U

Ryan Reynolds blazed a path that allows him to be an actor, entrepreneur, and more. “While I was obscenely privileged to star in movies, a lot of times they weren’t working,” he says. “That’s when I said, ‘I need to have some authorship here.’ ” https://t.co/7SPpbIABkc
A Canadian company’s stock is surging. Investors are apparently confusing it for the rebranded Facebook. https://t.co/ms2sLwjEoq
From @WSJopinion: The $1.75 trillion cost of the White House’s budget framework is phony, but the social and fiscal damage are real https://t.co/Qj3f7fkdhS

Mark Zuckerberg’s announcement that Facebook is focusing on the metaverse and changing its name to Meta Platforms Inc. is in many ways a personal rebranding as much as a corporate one https://t.co/mI5FYS9P2C

Patagonia is doubling down on its decision to stop all paid advertising on Facebook platforms, urging other companies to join in its boycott of the social-networking company as it faces widespread scrutiny following the release of internal documents https://t.co/dJOxFpxDyg
Take an early look at the front page of The Wall Street Journal https://t.co/IheHEeo6sh https://t.co/LZoTuqGZEW

Watch: Chick-fil-A's unconventional approach to business has helped make it the third biggest fast-food chain in the U.S. We get an inside look at the strategies driving the Atlanta-based company’s success. https://t.co/AhR1GMS74D
The chip shortage is worsening, with wait times lengthening and buyers hoarding products. Delivery dates in 2024 aren't unusual. https://t.co/F0tTWNad2F

The Securities and Exchange Commission is asking a federal judge to require Sen. Richard Burr’s brother-in-law to testify in an enforcement probe that examines possible insider trading by both men https://t.co/1uKS7s9aEl

Slightly under 40% of workers who are unvaccinated say they would leave their job if getting the Covid-19 vaccine was mandated by their employer or if they were required to get tested for the virus weekly, according to the results of a new survey https://t.co/EmCu35X9vc
